post_title: US nuclear industry upbeat on small reactors, despite setback
title: Small Reactors: The Future of Carbon-Free Power?
post_content:
Title: The Future of Small Modular Reactors: A Carbon-Free Power Source

Despite setbacks, including the recent cancellation of a next-generation nuclear plant, supporters of carbon-free nuclear power remain optimistic about the future of small modular reactors (SMRs). These compact, factory-built nuclear plants could potentially convince wary customers and contribute to a greener energy landscape.

The US energy company NuScale recently abandoned its SMR project in Idaho due to soaring costs. Initially estimated at $5.3 billion, the project's price tag skyrocketed to $9.3 billion, ultimately leading to its termination. MV Ramana, a professor at the University of British Columbia, predicted that this collapse should signal the end for SMRs. However, there is evidence suggesting otherwise.

Mason Lester, an analyst at S&P Global Commodity Insights, highlighted several positive developments in the US nuclear sector over the past year. One such example is the Darlington project in Ontario, Canada, where GE Hitachi aims to begin producing power with its new SMR design, the BWRX-300, by 2029. Pending regulatory approval, construction work will commence in 2025. The Tennessee Valley Authority, a federally-owned US power company, has also invested in the BWRX-300.

Marcia Burkey, chief financial officer at TerraPower, noted that while some cost increases are not specific to nuclear power, there is a need to innovate and address these challenges. TerraPower plans to build a nuclear reactor in Kemmerer, Wyoming, at a retired coal plant, utilizing a unique "molten chloride" technology that operates at higher temperatures than conventional reactors, increasing efficiency.

Standardization and risk sharing are crucial to lowering costs across multiple projects. Another promising venture is Ultra Safe Nuclear Corporation's Micro-Modular Reactor (MMR) assembly plant, set to open in Gadsden, Alabama, in 2027.

Although China and Russia have operational small reactors, the United States is ahead of Europe in this area of nuclear development. Sylvain Cognet-Dauphin of S&P Global Insights noted that Europe is lagging behind the US in SMRs. Legislation has been

post_title: What we've learned from the women behind the AI revolution
title: Women Leading the AI Revolution: Insights from Global Policy to Safety Engineering
post_content:
Title: The Women Shaping the Future of Artificial Intelligence

Introduction:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a rapidly growing field, filled with opportunities and challenges. While the media often focuses on the male figures dominating this industry, there are numerous women who are making significant contributions to AI technology, policy, and safety. In this blog post, we will highlight a series of interviews conducted by TechCrunch's Dominic-Madori Davis and Kyle Wiggers, focusing on the inspiring stories of women in AI.

The Interviews:
Davis and Wiggers have been hosting insightful conversations with women in AI, covering a wide range of topics including global policy, academia, and safety engineering. Here are some of the remarkable women they've interviewed:

1. Irene Solaiman, head of global policy at Hugging Face
Irene Solaiman is responsible for shaping the ethical and responsible use of AI at Hugging Face, a leading AI company. In her interview, Solaiman discusses her role in creating guidelines and policies that ensure the ethical application of AI technology. She also shares her insights on the importance of transparency and collaboration in the AI industry.
meta_desc: Meta Description: Discover inspiring women shaping AI's future! Read about their roles in global policy, responsible AI, and ethical AI development. Join the AI revolution with a diverse perspective.

post_title: Working from home isn't going away, even if some CEOs wish it would
title: Balancing CEO Wishes & Remote Work Trends
post_content:
THE FUTURE OF WORK: REMOTE VS. IN-OFFICE – A Deep Dive

The landscape of work has significantly shifted in recent years, with remote work becoming increasingly popular. However, some CEOs are pushing for a return to traditional office settings. This article will delve into the pros and cons of both remote and in-office work, analyzing the latest data and expert opinions.

THE RISE OF REMOTE WORK

In the late 1980s, working from home was a rare occurrence. However, the turn of the millennium saw a gradual increase in remote work, with the pandemic further accelerating this trend. According to USA Today, 14% of U.S. workers currently work from home full-time, a number projected to reach 20% by 2023. A staggering 58% of white-collar employees desire flexibility in their work schedules, allowing them to work from home a few days a week.

OPPOSITION TO REMOTE WORK

Despite the growing demand for remote work, some CEOs are pushing against this trend. Amazon and IBM are among the companies attempting to lure employees back to the office, with Amazon CEO Andy Jassy even suggesting that remote workers may face unfavorable consequences. Big tech CEOs like Elon Musk and Marc Benioff have publicly criticized remote work, citing concerns over productivity and the need for in-person collaboration.

THE PRODUCTIVITY QUESTION

But do employees truly become more productive in an office setting? A study by the University of Pittsburgh Katz School of Business found that return-to-office mandates do not necessarily improve firm performance. In fact, such mandates may harm employee satisfaction. Furthermore, research indicates that employees value flexibility over location, with remote work contributing to higher levels of engagement and productivity.

BURNOUT AND EMPLOYEE SATISFACTION

Companies enforcing a return to the office are experiencing higher rates of employee burnout. This is unsurprising, as the argument for in-office work often centers around increased collaboration and productivity, which are difficult to maintain when employees are exhausted.

THE BENEFITS OF A REMOTE WORKFORCE

Remote work offers numerous advantages, including access to a
meta_desc:
global talent pool, reduced overhead costs, and a smaller environmental footprint. By embracing remote work, businesses can tap into a diverse range of skilled professionals from around the world, fostering innovation and creativity. Furthermore, remote work eliminates the need for costly office spaces and commutes, resulting in significant cost savings for both employers and employees. Lastly, remote work reduces carbon emissions, contributing to a healthier environment.

Flexibility is the key to a successful workforce. Companies that adopt a hybrid approach, combining the best aspects of both remote and in-office work, are likely to thrive in this new landscape. By catering to the diverse needs and preferences of their workforce, businesses can foster a more engaged, productive, and satisfied workforce.

post_title: When it comes to building startups in Boston, success begets success
post_content:
Building Successful Startups in Boston: A Thriving Ecosystem

Boston has become a hub for successful startups, with Hubspot, iRobot, Wayfair, Acquia, Carbon Black, and Klaviyo leading the charge. This thriving ecosystem generates wealth, fosters new generations of entrepreneurs, and creates an environment where ideas can be transformed into reality. The city's success story is due to several factors, including its supportive universities, abundant talent, and a robust investment landscape.

A Key Ingredient: Higher Education Institutions

Boston's startup ecosystem owes much of its success to the city's 35 colleges and universities, with institutions like Harvard, MIT, and Tufts contributing significantly to the flow of new ideas and talent. The presence of these educational powerhouses creates a rich environment for innovation, with research and infant innovations frequently spun off into startups.

Emily Knight, President of The Engine Accelerator, an MIT spinoff, emphasizes the importance of these universities in the startup ecosystem. According to Knight, "There is a lot of research and a lot of infant innovation being translated into companies coming out of these universities."

Lily Lyman, a partner at Underscore VC, echoes Knight's sentiments. Underscore VC, a Boston-based investment firm, has built a strong portfolio with about a third of its companies originating from the local university system. "It's a huge piece of the puzzle and honestly, it's a big reason why we are here in Boston and why we are bullish on Boston," Lyman explains.

Talent: The Lifeblood of Startups

The abundance of STEM talent produced by Boston's universities is another critical factor in the city's successful startup landscape. Rudina Seseri, Managing Director at Glasswing Ventures, highlights the importance of this constant flow of skilled professionals.

"If you just think of the raw talent, and then you look at where the AI and ML talent is coming from, there is an incredible pool of talent, which matches up nicely with my firm's investments in enterprise and cybersecurity," says Seseri.

The Perfect Mix: Tech, R&D, and Talent

The combination of technology, research and development, and the constant influx of skilled professionals in Boston creates the
meta_desc: Discover why Boston has become a thriving hub for successful startups. Its unique blend of supportive universities, talented professionals, and a robust investment landscape fosters innovation and growth. Top-tier institutions like Harvard, MIT, and Tufts generate a steady stream of new ideas and skilled individuals, fueling the local startup ecosystem. As a result, Boston boasts prominent startups such as Hubspot, iRobot, Wayfair, Acquia, Carbon Black, and Klaviyo, contributing to the global economy and solidifying its reputation as a premier destination for entrepreneurs and investors.

post_title: Price of zero-day exploits rises as companies harden products against hackers
title:
Title: "Zero-Day Exploit Prices Soar: A New Era of Cybersecurity Arms Race"

In the ever-evolving digital age, the value of zero-day exploits, tools targeting software vulnerabilities, has skyrocketed. Companies like Crowdfense and Zerodium broker these exploits to government agencies. This piece explores the rising cost of zero-day exploits, their significance in cybersecurity, and the challenges for threat intelligence teams in mitigating their impact.

The Cost of Zero-Day Exploits Soars

Crowdfense, a startup dealing in zero-day exploits, recently updated its pricing. Notable changes include:

- iOS zero-days: $5-7 million (up from $3 million)
- Android zero-days: up to $5 million (up from $3 million)
- Chrome and Safari zero-days: up to $3.5 million and $3 million, respectively
- WhatsApp and iMessage zero-days: $3-5 million

These increases reflect the growing difficulty in exploiting software as companies enhance security.

The Challenges in Exploiting Software and Devices

Dustin Childs, Trend Micro ZDI, highlights the increasing difficulty in exploiting software and devices year after year. Shane Huntley, Google's Threat Analysis Group, agrees, noting that as more zero-day vulnerabilities are discovered and platform protections improve, the cost for attackers rises.
post_content:
Title: The Soaring Value of Zero-Day Exploits: A New Era of Digital Arms Race

Introduction

In today's digital age, the race between cybersecurity and cybercrime has taken a new turn. Zero-day exploits, tools that take advantage of unpatched vulnerabilities in software, are now worth millions of dollars. Companies like Crowdfense and Zerodium are at the forefront of this underground market, acquiring these exploits and reselling them to government agencies and contractors. This article will delve into the rising prices of zero-day exploits, their significance in the world of cybersecurity, and the challenges faced by threat intelligence teams in mitigating their impact.

The Rising Prices of Zero-Day Exploits

Crowdfense, a startup specializing in acquiring and reselling zero-day exploits, recently updated its price list. The new figures reveal a substantial increase in the value of these tools since the company's last price list was published in 2019. Some of the noteworthy changes include:

 A rise in the payout for iOS zero-days from $3 million to between $5 and $7 million.
 An increase in the value of Android zero-days from $3 million to up to $5 million.
 An elevation in payouts for Chrome and Safari zero-days, with the former now valued at up to $3.5 million and the latter at up to $3 million.
 An appreciation in the worth of WhatsApp and iMessage zero-days, now valued at between $3 and $5 million.

These increases are a reflection of the growing difficulty in exploiting software and devices as companies like Apple, Google, and Microsoft enhance their security measures.

The Challenges in Exploiting Software and Devices

Dustin Childs, head of threat awareness at Trend Micro ZDI, emphasizes that the process of exploiting software and devices should become increasingly difficult year after year. This is evident in the decreasing number of zero-days being discovered and the time and resources required to find new ones. Shane Huntley, the head of Google's Threat Analysis Group, concurs, stating that as more zero-day vulnerabilities are discovered and platform protections improve, the cost of findings for attackers rises.

In 2
meta_desc:
Meta Description: Uncover the world of zero-day exploits' soaring values, their impact on cybersecurity, and strategies to mitigate their effects. Learn about the digital arms race and its consequences for threat intelligence teams.

post_title: EarliTec Diagnostics raises $21.5M to help diagnose autism earlier
title: EarliTec Diagnostics Secures $21.5M for Early Autism Diagnosis
post_content:
Autism Diagnosis Revolutionized: EarliTec Diagnostics' Game-Changing Approach

Autism, a complex neurodevelopmental condition, affects 1 in 36 children in the United States, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial for improved developmental outcomes. EarliTec Diagnostics, an Atlanta-based startup, is revolutionizing autism diagnosis with its innovative system, which has recently secured funding to expand its reach. This article will delve into the groundbreaking work of EarliTec Diagnostics and explore the growing interest in autism-focused healthcare startups from venture capitalists (VCs).

EarliTec Diagnostics' Innovative Solution

EarliTec Diagnostics has developed an FDA-authorized system that uses artificial intelligence (AI) to help clinicians diagnose autism in children as young as 16 months old. The process involves the child watching short videos and social interactions on a screen for 12 minutes while the device tracks the child's eye movements. Children with autism exhibit different focusing patterns compared to their neurotypical counterparts, allowing for early detection.

The startup recently raised a $21.5 million Series B round co-led by Nexus NeuroTech Ventures and Venture Investors. This funding will enable EarliTec to expand its commercialization efforts, improve assessment and treatment options, and potentially broaden the age range of children it can diagnose.

Traditional autism diagnosis typically involves lengthy three- to four-hour assessments with potential waitlists. EarliTec Diagnostics' 12-minute test offers a faster, more accessible solution for clinicians, allowing them to work with more children and provide quicker diagnoses, which can significantly impact a child's developmental trajectory.

Growing Interest in Autism-Focused Healthcare Startups

Recent years have seen increasing interest and investment in autism-focused healthcare startups, such as EarliTec Diagnostics. This trend can be attributed to a growing awareness of autism prevalence and the significant unmet need for effective diagnostic tools and treatments.

For example, the Autism Impact Fund recently closed a $60 million fund, 20% higher than its initial $50 million

post_title: Magnets are switching up the keyboard game
title: Magnetic Switches Revolutionize Mechanical Keyboards: Adjustable Actuation Points
post_content:
The Future of Mechanical Keyboards: Magnetic Switches

The mechanical keyboard market has seen a significant boom in recent years, with brands like Akko, Drop, Ducky, Epomaker, and Keychron becoming popular choices for enthusiasts. The variety of layouts and customizable parts has grown exponentially, but the industry is ready for a fresh wave of innovation. Enter magnetic switches, a new technology that brings a unique feature to the table: quickly adjustable actuation points.

The Basics of Mechanical Keyboard Switches

Before diving into magnetic switches, it's essential to understand how standard mechanical keyboard switches work. In a typical mechanical switch, two metal leaves close an electrical circuit when a key is pressed, registering a keystroke. The stem's shape and legs determine the switch's feel, with linear switches having smooth stems and tactile switches offering resistance. A spring controls the resistance, and the overall switch design affects feel, sound, and keypress registration.

Introducing Magnetic Switches

Magnetic switches, made popular by Dutch keyboard startup Wooting, utilize magnets and springs instead of electrical circuits. They rely on the Hall Effect to sense changes in the magnetic field as a key is pressed. This technology has been around since the 1960s but has recently gained popularity in the mechanical keyboard community.

Adjustable Actuation Points

Magnetic switches offer a significant advantage: adjustable actuation points. This feature allows users to change the distance required to register a keystroke. For instance, gamers might prefer a 0.1-millimeter actuation point, while typists might opt for a 2.5-millimeter point to prevent accidental keystrokes.

Additional Customization

Apart from adjustable actuation points, magnetic switches enable customization of key release points and macro creation. Users can assign multiple actions to a single key, which can register different actions based on the key's position during the press. However, magnetic switches still rely on springs for resistance, and there isn't yet a standardized design for these switches, making compatibility an issue.

The Impact of Magnetic Switches

Magnetic switches bring a new level of customization to mechanical keyboards, allowing users to fine-tune their keyboards to suit specific needs. This
meta_desc: Discover magnetic switches: the future of mechanical keyboards. Adjustable actuation points, customizable release points, and macro creation provide unparalleled customization. With further development, magnetic switches could become a standard feature in high-end keyboards. MagneticSwitches MechanicalKeyboards [17 words]

post_title: TechCrunch Mobility: Apple layoffs, an EV price reckoning and another Tesla robotaxi promise
title: Navigating the Evolving Landscape of EVs: Affordability, Autonomy, and Partnerships
post_content:
Title: Navigating the Evolving Landscape of EVs: Affordability, Autonomy, and Partnerships

Welcome to this week's edition of TechCrunch Mobility, your go-to source for the latest news and trends in transportation innovation. If you enjoy the content, consider subscribing to our newsletter.

EV Affordability: A Major Hurdle

The automotive industry recently reported Q1 sales, and it appears that pricing plays a crucial role in the sales of electric vehicles (EVs). A recent survey by Edmunds highlights a significant gap between consumer preferences and market availability: 47% of consumers aim to purchase an EV priced below $40,000, while only 22% are interested in EVs priced below $30,000. Unfortunately, no new EVs are priced below $30,000, and only four models fall below the $40,000 threshold.

The affordability challenge has forced automakers to slash prices and reconsider future EV launches. Ford has delayed launches and shifted resources towards hybrids, while Tesla has resorted to price cuts and promoting its Full Self-Driving software for $12,000. However, this two-pronged approach might not be enough to overcome the affordability barrier.

Ghost Autonomy Closes Shop

Ghost Autonomy, a startup that had raised over $220 million, recently confirmed its closure. Founded in 2017, the company pivoted several times before focusing on urban environments and last-mile delivery. According to CEO John Hayes, the company was unable to secure funding to bring the product to market.

Maniv's New Fund: A Bright Spot for Startups

Maniv, an Israel and NYC-based VC firm, raised $140 million in a new fund to invest in early-stage startups at the intersection of mobility, transportation, and energy. Maniv has expanded its geographic reach and investor base, focusing on deep tech, decarbonization, and the digitization of the transportation sector. The fund's investors include BNP Paribas Personal Finance, Shell, Enterprise Mobility, and Toyota Motor Corp.'s Woven Capital.

Add

post_title: The Journal app makes your iPhone 'Discoverable by Others' by default. How to disable it
title: Apple's Journal App: Disable 'Discoverable by Others' for Privacy; iOS 17.2 Update
post_content:
Apple's New Journal App: Capturing Moments with a Cautionary Note on Privacy

With the release of iOS 17.2, Apple introduced its Journal app, designed to help users document and reflect on their daily experiences. The app uses machine learning to provide personalized suggestions, but one feature has caught users' attention: the 'Discoverable by Others' setting. This feature, enabled by default, allows other iPhones to detect your device via Bluetooth and suggest shared moments. While there is no inherent privacy violation, some users may feel uncomfortable with this level of detectability. Let's explore how to disable this feature and delve into the app's functionality and privacy concerns.

How to Disable the 'Discoverable by Others' Setting

To protect your privacy, you can disable the 'Discoverable by Others' setting in the Journal app. Here's how:

1. Open your iPhone's Settings app.
2. Scroll down and select Privacy & Security.
3. Find and tap Journaling Suggestions.
4. Toggle off the 'Discoverable by Others' setting.

Where is the Journal App on iOS 17?

The Journal app was automatically added to iPhones with the iOS 17.2 update. If you can't find it on your home screen, search for it in your list of installed apps or re-download it from the App Store if you've deleted it.

Addressing Privacy Concerns

Although the Journal app doesn't share personal information or journal content, the 'Discoverable by Others' feature may still raise privacy concerns. This setting allows other iPhones to detect your device via Bluetooth and suggest shared moments. While Apple maintains that this information is stored locally and not shared with the company, some users may still feel uncomfortable.

If you're among those who prefer not to have this level of detectability, you can disable the 'Discoverable by Others' setting and continue using the Journal app for personal reflection. Keep in mind that this feature is designed to improve the user experience by providing suggestions based on activities and interactions, but it's not mandatory for enjoying the app's core functionality.

In conclusion, Apple's Journal app offers a unique way to capture and reflect on your everyday moments. While there are valid concerns regarding the 'Discoverable

post_title: Canoo reveals it paid for CEO's jet, AT&T leaks records and X announces NSFW plans
title: Microsoft, Quantinuum's Quantum Breakthrough & Apple's Home Robot: Top Tech News
post_content:
Welcome to this week’s tech roundup, where we distill the most interesting developments in the tech sphere into a concise and engaging format for you. Let’s dive in!

Y Combinator’s Demo Days: Skepticism and Innovation
----------------------------------------------------

Y Combinator, the renowned startup accelerator, recently held its Demo Days, and our venture desk team covered the event with a discerning eye. The two-day affair showcased a myriad of startups, and our team’s in-depth analysis can be found in their day one and day two coverage, complete with an AI roundup and insightful commentary.

Meanwhile, the tech world kept spinning with other significant events:

 Microsoft and Quantinuum’s Quantum Leap

Microsoft and quantum computing startup Quantinuum announced a scientific breakthrough, allegedly running thousands of experiments on a quantum computer without a single error. This milestone, which has long eluded the industry, could pave the way for future advancements in quantum computing.

 Apple’s Home Robot Project

Apple, fresh from canceling its autonomous EV project, is reportedly shifting its focus to home robots. Although details are still being ironed out, Apple Home and AI executives have been tasked with developing a household robotics project.

This week also saw its fair share of news, funding developments, and analysis. Here are some highlights:

 Canoo, the EV startup, paid $1.7 million in 2023 to cover its CEO’s private jet rental, which is double the amount of revenue the company generated that year.
 AT&T reset millions of account passcodes after a massive data leak containing customer records surfaced online earlier in March.
 OpenAI now allows access to its flagship conversational AI, ChatGPT, without requiring users to create an account, albeit with some limitations.
 Microsoft introduced new versions of its Microsoft 365 and Office 365 subscription services, excluding Teams, its business collaboration chat offering, following EU regulatory scrutiny and complaints from rival Slack.

 Funding and Closures

Ghost Autonomy, a startup developing autonomous driving software for automaker partners, shut down after raising nearly $220 million. The reason for its closure
